texts.definition: The goal of forming a linear alignment of game elements.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of forming a linear alignment of game elements.</style>

Many games make use of the spatial relationship of game elements to cause effects in the game state. When the pieces have to form a line (typically defined by three game elements) for an effect to occur, this can be described as giving players the goal of Alignment. The goal usually requires the aligned elements to be next to each other. There are, however, games where this is not the case and Alignment is instead used to determine the movement paths of game elements, e.g. leaping in Draughts. Using the term Matching Tile Games, Jesper Juul provides an analysis of a group of games using a form of the pattern in the fourth chapter of his book A Casual Revolution: Reinventing Video Games and Their Players

A well known, and perhaps the simplest, game of <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tic-Tac-Toe">Tic-Tac-Toe</link></style> where the winner is the first to have three markers in horizontal, vertical or diagonal <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> in a three by three board. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hnefatafl">Hnefatafl</link></style> and other 'Tafl games' are believed to have rules that allow captures by surrounding a piece on two opposing sides. As mentioned above, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Draughts">Draughts</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> for

'Match 3' games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Staries">Staries</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Keeper">Zoo Keeper</link></style> all lets players swap game elements which are neighbors, removing them and rewarding the player with points if three or more game elements become aligned.
<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tetris">Tetris</link></style> uses the horizontal Alignment of blocks to remove them from the screen and increase the player's score.

The prime challenges that can be designed for <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> goals consist of how players can move or place the necessary game elements into the correct position and how game elements can be removed in order to hinder the completion of the <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style>, which are a type of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>. Due to these changes of a game the pattern introduced, it affects <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, or both. The difficulty of the goal can easily be increased by making the game elements move on their own or making them moveable by other players and introducing <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style>. The pattern is typically used in board games to create <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> after <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> has been achieved.

Although not directly a goal, the use of <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> to detect or attack other game elements has much in common with <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style>. Further, when players can detect <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or other target through other means and need to achieve <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> to perform certain activities, the two patterns do overlap since gaining <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> becomes the same as gaining an <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> without any <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> in between.
<style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> goals can also be created by modifying <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> is a form of <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style>, and offers the possibility of <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> by offering players clear visual <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> using the Gestalt Law of Closure. <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> can be a case of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style>, but does not have to be so, since the game elements involved in the <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> do not necessarily need to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style> between each other.

<style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> is typically used as a prerequisite for <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> where shots move instantaneously to the target, or the target is stationary, the action of <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> has <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> as a goal and typically required <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>. In other cases, <style="CurrentLink">Alignment</style> is typically a part of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>.
